newsitem.title: FRANCE: Low French water levels "worrying" - minister.
newsitem.headline: Low French water levels "worrying" - minister.

text.p: France's water levels, hit by weeks of dry weather, are worryingly low and unless it rains soon more regions may face water restrictions, environment minister Corinne Lepage said on Tuesday.
"We are in a worrying situation. Not alarming, but worrying. The water table is very low," Lepage told RTL radio in an interview.
She urged people voluntarily to cut their use of water and said partial irrigation bans might have to be extended to the north and west of the country.
Farmers in six provinces or departments in the centre of the country have been hit with partial irrigation bans due to the dry spell.
"Even when there are no restrictions, each us must be aware that water is a rare resource and that it must be used in an economical manner," Lepage said.
Fears of prolonged drought in France's grain regions pushed up the local price of wheat last week as grain traders worried about damage to crop yields.

The south of France is now suffering from a so-called agricultural drought, which starts to damage vegetation after about three weeks without rain but is reversible, the national meteorological service said last week.
France has had virtually no rain since January 25, it said.
